an5.57:4.1: “Mendicants, a woman or a man, a layperson or a renunciant should often reflect on these five subjects.
an5.57:4.3: ‘My nature is to grow old, I am not exempt from old age.’ A woman or a man, a layperson or a renunciant should often reflect on this.
an5.57:4.4: ‘My nature is to get sick, I am not exempt from sickness.’ …
an5.57:4.5: ‘My nature is to die, I am not exempt from death.’ …
an5.57:4.6: ‘I must be parted and separated from all I hold dear and beloved.’ …
an5.57:4.7: ‘I am the owner of my deeds and heir to my deeds. Deeds are my womb, my relative, and my refuge.
an5.57:4.8: I shall be the heir of whatever deeds I do,
an5.57:4.10: A woman or a man, a layperson or a renunciant should often reflect on this.
an5.57:5.1: What is the advantage for a woman or a man, a layperson or a renunciant of often reflecting like this: ‘My nature is to grow old, I am not exempt from old age’?
an5.57:5.2: There are sentient beings who, drunk on the vanity of youth, do bad things by way of body, speech, and mind.
an5.57:5.3: Reflecting often on this subject, they entirely give up the vanity of youth, or at least reduce it.
an5.57:5.4: This is the advantage for a woman or a man, a layperson or a renunciant of often reflecting like this: ‘My nature is to grow old, I am not exempt from old age’.
an5.57:6.1: What is the advantage of often reflecting like this: ‘My nature is to get sick, I am not exempt from sickness’?
an5.57:6.2: There are sentient beings who, drunk on the vanity of health, do bad things by way of body, speech, and mind.
an5.57:6.3: Reflecting often on this subject, they entirely give up the vanity of health, or at least reduce it.
an5.57:6.4: This is the advantage of often reflecting like this: ‘My nature is to get sick, I am not exempt from sickness’.
an5.57:7.1: What is the advantage of often reflecting like this: ‘My nature is to die, I am not exempt from death’?
an5.57:7.2: There are sentient beings who, drunk on the vanity of life, do bad things by way of body, speech, and mind.
an5.57:7.3: Reflecting often on this subject, they entirely give up the vanity of life, or at least reduce it.
an5.57:7.4: This is the advantage of often reflecting like this: ‘My nature is to die, I am not exempt from death’.
an5.57:8.1: What is the advantage of often reflecting like this: ‘I must be parted and separated from all I hold dear and beloved’?
an5.57:8.2: There are sentient beings who, aroused by desire and lust for their dear and beloved, do bad things by way of body, speech, and mind.
an5.57:8.3: Reflecting often on this subject, they entirely give up desire and lust for their dear and beloved, or at least reduce it.
an5.57:8.4: This is the advantage of often reflecting like this: ‘I must be parted and separated from all I hold dear and beloved’.
an5.57:9.1: What is the advantage of often reflecting like this: ‘I am the owner of my deeds and heir to my deeds. Deeds are my womb, my relative, and my refuge.
an5.57:9.2: I shall be the heir of whatever deeds I do, whether good or bad’?
an5.57:9.4: There are sentient beings who do bad things by way of body, speech, and mind.
an5.57:9.5: Reflecting often on this subject, they entirely give up bad conduct, or at least reduce it.
an5.57:9.6: This is the advantage for a woman or a man, a layperson or a renunciant of often reflecting like this: ‘I am the owner of my deeds and heir to my deeds. Deeds are my womb, my relative, and my refuge.
an5.57:9.7: I shall be the heir of whatever deeds I do, whether good or bad.’
an5.57:10.2: ‘It’s not just me whose nature is to grow old, not being exempt from old age. For all sentient beings grow old according to their nature, as long as they come and go, die and are reborn.’
an5.57:10.3: When they reflect often on this subject, the path arises.
an5.57:10.4: They cultivate, develop, and make much of it.
an5.57:10.5: By doing so, they give up the fetters and eliminate the tendencies.
an5.57:11.1: ‘It’s not just me whose nature is to get sick, not being exempt from sickness. For all sentient beings get sick according to their nature, as long as they come and go, die and are reborn.’
an5.57:11.2: When they reflect often on this subject, the path arises.
an5.57:11.3: They cultivate, develop, and make much of it.
an5.57:11.4: By doing so, they give up the fetters and eliminate the tendencies.
an5.57:12.1: ‘It’s not just me whose nature is to die, not being exempt from death. For all sentient beings die according to their nature, as long as they come and go, die and are reborn.’
an5.57:12.2: When they reflect often on this subject, the path arises.
an5.57:12.3: They cultivate, develop, and make much of it.
an5.57:12.4: By doing so, they give up the fetters and eliminate the tendencies.
an5.57:13.1: ‘It’s not just me who must be parted and separated from all I hold dear and beloved. For all sentient beings must be parted and separated from all they hold dear and beloved, as long as they come and go, die and are reborn.’
an5.57:13.2: When they reflect often on this subject, the path arises.
an5.57:13.3: They cultivate, develop, and make much of it.
an5.57:13.4: By doing so, they give up the fetters and eliminate the tendencies.
an5.57:14.1: ‘It’s not just me who is the owner of my deeds and heir to my deeds. For all sentient beings are the owner of their deeds and heir to their deeds, as long as they come and go, die and are reborn.’
an5.57:14.7: When they reflect often on this subject, the path arises.
an5.57:14.8: They cultivate, develop, and make much of it.
an5.57:14.9: By doing so, they give up the fetters and eliminate the tendencies.”
an5.57:15.2: and so are old age and death.
an5.57:15.3: Though this is how their nature is,
an5.57:16.1: If I was to be disgusted
an5.57:16.2: with creatures whose nature is such,
an5.57:16.3: it would not be appropriate for me,
an5.57:16.4: since my life is just the same.
an5.57:17.2: I understood the reality without attachments.
an5.57:19.4: until the spiritual life is complete.”
